newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania to sign $200 mln Chase loan for oil.
newsitem.headline: Romania to sign $200 mln Chase loan for oil.

text.p: Romania will sign next week a long-delayed $200 million loan with Chase Manhattan Corp to allow monthly imports of 800,000 tonnes of crude oil through December, a senior industry official said on Wednesday.
Vifor Ionita, president of the state-run National Oil Company (CRP), said the accord for the syndicated loan arranged by Chase would be signed on February 3 in London.
"The credit, a revolving one, will help us carry out smoothly our import programme of 800,000 tonnes of crude a month for the rest of the year," Ionita told Reuters.
The loan, guaranteed by the government, would be given to the state Petrolexportimport SA, the country's main oil trader, with CRP as the beneficiary of the imports, he said.
CRP is a holding grouping Romania's 12 state-owned refineries, four transport and 41 oil distribution companies.
The signing of the accord with Chase will end months of delays caused by a legal dispute involving CRP and the private local General Trading and Investments Co SA (GTI) company.
Last October, GTI launched a court action to suspend the CRP, accusing it of monopolistic practices.
Chase suspended negotiations on the loan pending court clarification. It eventually accepted a government proposal to arrange the deal with Petrolexportimport.
The suspension of talks disrupted vital supplies of crude oil to refineries during the cold months. Motorists queued for days at petrol stations across Romania.
"Matters are clear now. We can also be part of the deal as last week the court rejected GTI's demands as groundless," Ionita said.
The CRP is to repay 68 percent of the $200 million loan with earnings from exports of products processed from the imported crude oil, he said.

The rest would come from the country's interbank market and from a fund created by the government last year for energy imports. The accord can be extended for a year if payments are made without disruption.
Romania needs to import large quantities of crude oil for domestic demand and to keep in operation its oversized refining capacity inherited from the former communist regime.
The Balkan country has a refining capacity of 34 million tonnes a year. Under a government project it will be cut to some 18 million over the next few years.
